Message.Title: The Fake World of Amazon
Message.Msg: They keep building more unprofitable warehouses, keep making unprofitable devices and they keep spending for tomorrow. rsiwiz, what is your justification for predicting $265 next week? Do you expect it to go higher just because it's been going higher, or do you have some kind of lucid valuation argument for why you think this stock is likely to go up another 7%? Readers of this board would appreciate hearing something more than seemingly arbitrary numbers thrown out, either up or down. Thank you in advance for your intelligent input that will advance the exchange of thoughts. Bears on this board seem to put out some pretty convincing arguments for overvaluation, but they've clearly been on the wrong side of the trade lately. But the bulls, with a few notable exceptions, seem to just laugh at bears and say "rock on." Does anyone want to at least speculate about what next Wednesday's announcement might mean for the fundamentals of AMZNs business, taking educated guesses at what JB has up his sleeve?

By doing it in an air hanger, my guess is that they will start up a travel site to compete with travelocity and expedia. One more non-core business to distract investors from the fact that they are losing money.
WSJ and Barron's reporting of an Ad supported touch screen Kindle Fire intro next week?
who needs the ad supporting screen? I personally hate all ads on my screen and i am sure most everybody goes. its so annoying

Message.Title: CapEx revenue leverage...
Message.Msg: Just a simple question for our resident "gurus" Nemesis, Geeg, NAS600 and Bruce (Bruce is actually a decent dude, just blind to the downside). Why is Amazon's revenue leverage from CapEx always dropping and so fast? Note, I did not say profits. I said revenue. Let's look at the past 3 years.... 2019: Revenue: $24,509,000 CapEx $373,000 CapEx Leverage (revenue / $ CapEx): 65.71 2010: Revenue: $34,204,000 CapEx $979,000 CapEx Leverage (revenue / $ CapEx): 34.94 2011: Revenue: $48,077,000 CapEx $1,811,000 CapEx Leverage (revenue / $ CapEx): 26.55 Wake up people. Each dollar of revenue is requiring more and more CapEx all the time... You can do the same thing for the past 4 quarters. Here is a hint. The trend continues to get worse (down to 25.59 for TTM and 19.53 in the last quarter)... The story is nice. The reality is that AMZN is not getting the kind of leverage from its investments that a company like AAPL or GOOG gets from its investments. All of these cloud plays are a scam when you really start to dig deep to determine what is essentially recurring CapEx (which is almost like an operating expense) and what truly provides long lived leverage... Net free cash flow after investing, not operating cash flow, is a better indicator of the long run profitability of these ventures... The economics are not nearly as attractive as you've been led to believe...
